reviews.review_text: No game has ever had me say, 'How?' and 'What the f**k?' more than Party Hard.   Don't get me wrong, the concept is great and the game can be fun to play. I can see why people love it, however I found the experience more annoying and frustrating than fun during my playthrough and here's why...  -The line of site is almost completely broken in this game:   Victims and cops can see you and bodies behind objects and walls that should be impossible to see. Not to mention, the game tries to balance this by making their line of sight moderately short range taking away from the fun. I think the game could be much improved with longer lines of sight and improved obstructions of said line of sight. As of now it's pretty much flipping a coin on each kill unless you're totally secluded from everything else.  -Traps and placements are randomized every time the mission starts:  Now this is actually a cool and interesting feature but I'm afraid its a double-edged sword. More than often you find yourself spawning with barely any ways to kill or distract crowds with a near to zip chance of succeeding. Of course, there's players who seek this challenge and like to pull it off. I just feel an average player with moderate skill like me is going to find themselves restarting the mission over and over until there's at least one worthy trap.  -Every other map has a totally broken trap/phone call that can clean house hands free with zero work:  This is very unfortunate because maps with traps like these tend to lack good design and are thrown in there like a cheat to skip the mission. It's mind blowing not a single victim/guard cares if your phone call brings people to the party and are obvious threats knocking people out and killing left and right.  -The police/guards make no sense at all in this game, especially considering their methods of public safety:  Upon arrival the police almost always run over people killing them instantly. I'm sure most people wouldn't write this off as a bad thing because who cares, free kills. Wrong, I think it's beyond stupid as you can't even use this feature to your advantage like luring crowds into the street and getting the cops to run them over. The swat beat everyone down if they're called but for some reason you get 'BUSTED' for being beat down like anyone else. (The people beat down aren't even arrested.) Finally, the guards... These guys beat you down just for showing up. I can understand if they're at the front door serving as a bouncer like in the second mission, but otherwise it's a dumb mechanic. How would they know if you're invited or not with all the people and partying going on.   -Horrible blame and accusation system:  I can't even state how many times I was busted for doing nothing wrong at all. If anyone at all dies near the player everyone assumes its the player and calls the cops over for an arrest. Countless times I've been walking on the brinks of the map to try ang get away from people dying and cops who are passing by will stop to arrest me for walking away like everyone else. Sometimes it's its not the cops and just random people who will call the cops for no reason. An interesting yet broken feature is the ability for victims to accuse and call cops on other victims. This leads to the most random arrests I've ever seen and it doesn't help the player's experience as it can't really be triggered on purpose similarly to police running over victims...  -Handful of small bugs that aren't 'game breaking' but result in the player's death all the time:  Typically, the cops are supposed to leave and ignore any more crimes the second they have someone over their shoulder or have bagged all the bodies but I've been arrested with people over their shoulder's twice in my time playing. Is it a feature? Possibly. It sure doesn't look like it. These police have pretty broken behavior and do random things they shouldn't more than often.  Conclusion:  Overall the game is fun yes, but success is a crap shoot and mostly RNG. When I say it's RNG I mean RNG... Going back to replay the game with end game knowledge and skill barely helps in this game. The game offers a mediocre story with TERRIBLE voice acting. The only real replay value in this game comes from the steam workshop allowing the player to download other player's missions and play them. Note, there ARE unlockable characters in this game with some really good pros but, they have horrible cons that render them useless. People say this game is a 'stealth' game but it really isn't at all.  I would recommend waiting for a sale to pick this game up. I think it's worth a playthrough but isn't an amazing game you'll be playing a lot. Heck, I'll probably forget about this game a week or so from now. I don't mean this in a bad or rude way, the game just didn't leave a memorable impact on me at all.   Side Note for Hotline Miami fans:  People compare this game to Hotline Miami all the time, but the two are nothing at all alike aside from being a masked killer who cleans house. If you're looking for a good alternative to Hotline Miami 1&2, I would recommend Deadbolt and not this. Deadbolt features a 2D world with one hit kills. It provides better challenge that requires planning very much like Hotline Miami.  Final Rating: 4/10

I really wanted to like this game. The art looks great, the concept is interesting, and when it goes right it can be a lot of fun. The problem is the enjoyment of the game is hampered by sheer randomness and the time it takes to play. Hotline Miami is fun because while it's difficult, death is cheap and it doesn't feel like a waste of time. Here your default character moves painfully slow, levels take a fair amount of time to play, and your ability to succeed hinges on what traps spawn in and how/when people walk by them.  Thus it leads to situations where you can feel like you played a level perfectly and fail due to bad luck or wind up boringly plucking people off one at a time while completing a level often isn't as satisfying as you think it would be because it came down to the happy bounce of a half dozen people walked in front of an exploding oven at the right time.  I won't fault anyone for enjoying it, but this game didn't do it for me. I typically enjoy slower paced, thinking games, but maybe I don't have the skillset for this one. It was just a bit too random to be fun and the levels take too much time to replay on failure, leading to it getting frustrating just a bit quickly for me. With one of any number of minor tweaks (bit faster movement speed, fewer people in a level, less random trap placement, etc) I think I could really recommend it, but as it is I'd have to say no thanks if I had to buy it again.

I really tried to enjoy this one. The art and presentation are incredible and the music is fitting although not nearly as memorable and creative as Hotline Miami. That's where all possible praise ends, as gameplay quickly devovles into a waiting game where you slowly cull a ridiculously excessive crowd while hoping the arbitrary AI coupled with the basically non-functional run button don't screw you over, forcing you to start over in a newly randomized level.   The entirety of gameplay offered here is waiting for people to separate, then walking up to tap X and back away. If you get lucky and don't get spotted - or don't get randomly designated as the killer by a cop on the other side of the map that may or may not end up being impossible to outrun - your reward is more waiting for your next faceless generic victim until you eventually wipe out the other several dozen party goers. Knife swings don't connect far too often and there are countless visual bugs and strange hitboxes. The bouncers can sometimes spot you across a room and kill you from outside of your own attack range, other times you can walk right past them or they'll miss an attack despite your sprites literally overlapping. Events and character behavior are so erratic that any possible strategy goes out the window in favour of capricious trial and error.   There are about 1-5 traps per level, often implied to be a core feature. Some are interesting but all require you to mindlessly sit on your ♥♥♥ until someone wanders close enough, netting you a grand total of one kill each and forcing you back to the idiotic knife mechanics to kill everyone else. Timed and explosive traps take so long to activate that the AI will have wandered off from the explosion.  -Good art -Decent music -Terrible story bordering on cringe worthy -Horribly amateur voices to the point where they'd be better off silent -Thoroughly unenjoyable level designs with excessive amounts of enemies -Levels that only get more repetitive and offer less room for creativity as it goes on -Idiotically designed traps -Arbitrary AI and often random, unavoidable failures -Glitches  -Even when functioning correctly, the AI of cops and guards feels very random and their methods nonsensical -The SWAT teams are even worse, as far as making any kind of sense in their actions -Very shallow mechanics with no experimentation -Even with enough patience for all the waiting you will not find a rewarding experience -Barely lines up with its own description and promised features -Boring, above all else. Don't buy it.  Rating 1/5

By no means is Party Hard a terrible game, but its balance and pacing sabotage an initially fun concept like its protagonist sabotages household appliances. The idea of playing a teen-slashing, B-movie serial killer that makes use of ridiculous traps and opportunistic kills is foundationally pretty great. The chief problem, for me, was that the number of traps and environmental kills you can employ are pretty steeply limited in each stage. By the time all those options are exhausted, you've made only a modest dent in the stock of hapless partygoers you're supposed to slaughter your way through, and the fun part is over. The inevitable next phase of the game isn't an exercise in strategy or cleverness - it's really all just about waiting after that. Waiting for someone to stumble into prime murdering position, waiting for the risk of being found with the body to elapse, waiting for police or other emergency services to leave the scene - all just so you can repetitively hack people up with the same knife in the same way. Each level has a strong start that peters out fast. Couple that with some significant bugs that can cost you an otherwise immaculately played round, and in the end, I really just can't recommend it for purchase. This was a game that started off great on the drawing board, but lacked a clear vision for how to turn that idea into game mechanics.

Not unless it's on sale. Than it becomes a tentative yes.  For the first few hours I was having a blast and laughing one hell of a lot at the black humor. Than you discover that there's really not any more mechanics and it gets pretty boring and grindy.  -Each level you kill everyone. That is the only objective. -90% of traps in the stage can only be used once. And a lot have really short ranges that npcs never get near so you will only use them when a cop is chasing you. -Most levels boil down to picking people off one by one as they walk off by themselves. Fun for a bit, but after the 20th one it gets pretty old. And you will be doing this each mission. -Only real difference from mission to mission is the different layouts (usually with less places to murder people unseen) and a few specific traps. Feels very samey after awhile since the gameplay doesn't really get mixed up.  Honestly, I'd consider the game a really good base and just needs a lot more content to keep levels from becoming boring. Specific targets, more dynamic things you can do to try to end the party, carrying multiple items and choosing which you can bring with you (unlocking them), and so on. Really feels like a lot of missed opportunities. I really don't regret buying it since I got it pretty cheap, but I can see it not being for everyone.  And yes the miami mission was the last I played. I looked up how to beat it, just really have no interest to progress farther at this point.

If you are anything like me and are into strategy games and dark humor, then this game definitely delivers even harder than that pizza place that has a rule about getting the food to you in 30 minutes or giving you the pizza for free.  Serial Killer Simulator.. err, I mean, Party Hard is a game where you start out playing as a bloke trying to get some sleep, thus having to eliminate his partyloving neighbors. As the game progresses, you become quite the notorious killer, travelling the US to introduce avid partygoers to the blade of your knife. You also unlock additional characters to play as, each with a specific trait that defines their playstyle. In addition to using your trusty switchblade, you can also off people by setting up various traps at parties to make it look like an accident.  The different parties, traps and characters bring a nice variety to the table, although the core mechanic of the game remains the same - kill all the unsuspecting partygoers and don't get caught. The part of not being caught can be a dash tricky sometimes, which brings out the strategy part in this game. If you are looking to be knees deep in blood while flailing your matchete-equipped arms around like you're two windmills at all times, this is probably more of a Getting Arrested Simulator for you, meaning this game is probably not the best choice of entertainment for you in particular, unless you are into that sort of thing, of course. I don't judge.  If you, like me, are a sneaky dude getting a kick out of setting your party-enthusiast victims up to be trampled by a zebra or unleashing a zombie apocalypse at a beach party, step right in and grab a knife. A dark sense of humor is recommended, this game doesn't take itself seriously and doesn't encourage you to do so either. I mean, if it did, it would probably be not on Steam but in the ISIS training materials.  Party Hard does come with a handful of glitches, nothing major but be prepared for slight inconveniences or a few of 'Why did that just happen right there????????' moments. If you're anything like me though, the latter will probably be because you did dumb stuff and are too proud or blind to own up to it.  Anyway, if you're anything like me and are hopelessly procrastinating doing your school project, work or household chores, this game might be relevant to your interests.

Think Commandos meets Postal meets Hotline Miami meets Hitman. Kill off the entire party without getting spotted, and if you are, either quickly get away or change clothes (if you have 'em). Party Hard offers a gameplay that's mostly suited for those that are patient and aim for perfectionism. For the most part you cannot be impatient, as the game will surely strike your attempts down in one fell swoop. You need to survey the land, find choke points (quite literally) and exploit crowd behaviour if you want to be successful.  Party Hard is at its core a stealth game, where you have to go about various locations killing off everyone. You do this by stabbing them in the face when no one is watching, shoving people into barbeques, torture chambers or off the roof, or letting a bull go on a raging stampede through vast crowds. What tools you have at your disposal on each level is for the most part random, even though some are set pieces that will always be there. Some of the later levels -require- you to make most out of the extra equipment on the level, or otherwise you'll stand no chance.  On the negative side the game has the occasional bug, like cops getting stuck, people reappearing alive when you throw their corpses off the roof or someone spotting you through walls. If you get upset easily by cheap deaths, this will tear on your sanity. I had to reset levels as much as 10 or 15 times in a row because of random events that was out of my control. For the most part though, Party Hard delivers on the stealth aspect, and unlockable characters allows you to further expand on the premise. For instance, the ninja is hidden when standing still against a wall.  The soundtrack featured is well composed and suits the game well. The voice talent and story is complete garbage. However, you're not here for that.   You are here to Party Hard.

This game has an interesting concept and visual style, but it's ruined by its terrible execution of almost everything it tries for. You are required to kill every single person in every level. It also has a very serious story told by conversations between a cop investigating the killings and some other guy (don't know who he is, but some not-so-subtle hints lead me to believe that it's the killer). Unfortunately, the dialogue is awash in awful cliche, and the voice acting sounds like a teenager trying to emulate Sin City's narrator.  If you want to play a pink and purple tinted pixel-art game about a murderous psychopath, play Hotline Miami instead, as it beats this game in every single respect.

A stealth game with clunky controls, broken line-of-sight, a useless main attack, ineffective and sparse traps, indistinct visuals, psychic guard AI, and make-or-break RNG.   A nice idea in theory but utterly dreadful execution. The only winning strategy is to hide in an empty room and wait for people to come by so you can pick them off one-by-one. You have no real influence over their decisions, so you can be standing there for whole minutes at a time with nothing to do. Even once a character enters, killing them isn't as easy as it sounds, since your main attack only extends horizontally, and has about a five-pixel range at best. It's like watching paint dry and eventually it's hard not to get bored and leave, even though leaving means certain death at the hands of the clunky controls, psychic cops, and one-use-only escape mechanisms.  Finally, to top it all off, the slow movement speed and slug-like pace makes restarting a level a tedious frustration.  Overhyped and utterly overpriced - it's a game that's more enjoyable when you're watching a streamer play it and get frustrated than when you're the one actually playing it.

tl;dr -> If you ever have some serial killer urges, please play this game instead to avoid jail time.   I received a review copy of this game and was very excited to play it because I had seen many gameplay videos showcasing an element I love – crazy, mindless mass murdering. I was extremely pleased with my gameplay experience.  If you enjoy mindless violence, creative executions, serial killing, and retro pixel graphics, then you will enjoy this game.  The aesthetics are good – the amount of detail in the character models and everything in the game world is very high. The sound effects are good, and the music for each level is great; however, in certain levels the part where the track loops is quite obvious. The music helps to project a very retro-like atmosphere and feel. The story is decent, however, I personally find the voice-acting to be a bit sub-par (although there definitely is a certain charm behind each voice).  Controls are simple and easy to familiarize yourself with, however, I strongly recommend using a controller to play. There isn’t really a tutorial, and in-game tips are provided via newspapers that you can read. This aspect could have been handled better, however, because the newspaper tips are randomized. An important thing to note is that “restarting” a level is a literal restart – everything in the level restarts from the beginning. The game has a very heavy RNG (random-number generator) element, however, restarting prevents the RNG from coming in. For example, if a stun bomb is located in a nearby item case, restarting will always cause a stun bomb to be located within (while dying/getting busted and restarting will randomize everything again). The learning curve is minimal to moderate depending on your patience (you will need a lot) and planning skill. Do not be surprised if you have to replay a level hundreds of times – I had quite the rage-fest when I had 50/51 people murdered and got arrested by police before I completed the level (this happened a handful of times to me already). The most challenging element of the game is probably accounting for the RNG that affects everything.  Gameplay consists of you killing everyone in a level so that you can go back to sleep. Your standard killing technique is a knife attack, however, the environment always offers a variety of other methods. For example, in some levels you can push people off the side of the rooftop, electrify a dance floor, or push someone into a ventilation fan. Disposing of dead bodies (via rooftops, garbage dumpsters, etc) is critical because people will panic from seeing corpses and will run around (breaking any route patterns) and/or call police.  If police are called in, an officer will arrive and body bag any corpses – an arrest attempt will occur if you have been spotted by a civilian. You can run away from police, but you have a very limited sprint bar – and police have faster walking speed than you. Preparing traps can kill police, however, they can still be set off by you or other civilians. Some levels have travel points (doors, slides, etc) that you can use to quickly dodge police, however, doing so when you are being chased will cause a Mario-like person to arrive and barricade certain points (use these as a last resort). Sometimes, police can arrest the wrong person, keeping things entertaining.  Maintaining stealth makes the game a lot easier, and a great starting tactic is to dispose of any sleeping people first – you can carry them and throw them off roofs, for example. Interestingly, carrying people does not alert anyone, nor does throwing them off roofs (or into other environmental hazards) in front of others. There is a button/key that shows you all the environmental objects you can interact with – and another useful thing it grants is an indicator on any people that can “see” you. This is great for gauging who will react if you kill someone.  You can make a single call per level, and this will summon a random NPC to the scene. Sometimes I’ve had a Jason-Chainsaw-like person arrive, who proceeded to kill a few people before being arrested. I’ve also had a pizza man arrive – dropping a pizza that attracts a lot of civilians. NPCs can also randomly arrive to the area, and I’ve had a party of civilians show up – much to my dismay because that meant more people to kill.  There are item cases in many of the levels, and sometimes a black market dealer will come and offer you a free item. Items include a stun grenade, dynamite, and (my favorite) a smoke grenade. When using the smoke grenade, you are granted invisibility in a small radius – my favorite tactic is to smoke a dense area and kill as many civilians as possible before the smoke dissipates.  To keep things interesting, there are unlockable characters. I have unlocked the Jason-like character, and selecting him starts me off with a powerful chainsaw.  After playing for a few hours, I realized a very, very efficient way to kill a lot of civilians is to camp near a telephone (or a chokepoint leading to one) and to just kill everyone that tries to pass by/call police. This is not as effective when you have not cleared certain areas of a level – like one that has a second phone. Doing this can allow you to chain massive score combos. Achievement hunters will have an exciting time trying to 100% this game.  Overall, the gameplay is lots of fun and very entertaining – especially with the variety of RNG events. Levels can be frustrating when you are so close to completion, but get busted for whatever reason, however, once you actually overcome these you will be happy for your achievement. The RNG elements and unlockable characters add great replayability. Anyone interested in mindless massacres should definitely give this game a try.  Highly recommend! THE POSITIVE:  + The game can be challenging despite it's simple appearance and gameplay. + The game will definitely keep you on your toes on your initial playthrough due to the amount of unexpected random events and occurences. + Easy to understand core mechanics and get into the game after the initial tutorial level. + Despite the seemingly simple premise of letting yourself loose upon an unsuspecting crowd, the game does take some tact and planning to complete most of the levels, barring the fortunate accident in which all the random resources scattered about the map provide enough coverage to wipe out all the party-goers. + Level Editor for player made content, providing more bang for the buck. + Apparently Twitch compatibility, but I am not an user so I can't really say much about that. Have you ever found yourself trying to sleep whilst your obnoxious housemate hosts, what seems like, the loudest party ever? Banged on the wall, screamed and smiled with satisfaction as the volume drops? Imagine taking this impulse even further and murdering each and every attendee. This is Party Hard. A pixel art, murderous puzzler where the party may last just a little too long.  Party Hard follows the story of a sadistic, serial killer attending gatherings across the country with the intent of being the last one standing. Whereas this is usually achieved with the consumption of energy drinks, Party Hard pursues a slightly more savage approach. You play as Darius who grows frustrated by a local party preventing his nightly routine. Armed with a small knife, Darius ignores the standard protocol of calling the police and systematically slaughters everyone from the bouncers to the DJ.  The narrative focuses on Darius’s increasing bloodlust, as he travels between parties, leaving a trail of bodies behind. Detective John West, who leads the investigation, has his own motivation for catching the perpetrator as his own daughter suffered at the hands of the maniac at the first party. The story gives context to the party locations and circumstances surrounding them. You are only treated to these small cinematic scenes during loading times though as participating in these massacres are why you will be playing Party Hard.  The first level is a standard, college party seen in teen films. Shady characters smoke around a bonfire, lightweights fall asleep in the bathroom and raunchy adolescents fondle around the side of the house. Approaching the party, you have a challenging task ahead of you as fifty or more people could be attending the rave. Killing these party-goers is as simple as pressing a button to quickly stab them. The obstacle is the witnesses. Armed with a small amount of stamina, chasing potential spectators can be impossible and soon, after a call to the law enforcement, a cop has a warrant for your arrest. Evading the pursuing policeman is an option, however, each time you allude them, they will return faster and more determined than before. Being spotted is not the most effective method to stop the party so you can either eliminate victims out of eyeshot or use other tools available to you.  Although the structure of the level remains the same, the activity within them will change each time. Aside from the numbers attending the affair, entire rooms can transform too. What was once a lounge room could become a meth lab. A group of dancers could be replaced by a drug deal which ultimately is raided by armed SWAT officers who assist you in reducing the number of victims. This diversity and unpredictability will have you adapting to your surroundings.  Regardless of the layout, the objective remains the same. Kill everyone. The ever-changing level will assist you with this perverse goal. A punch bowl can be poisoned, a gas canister ignited or you can even lure an advancing cop into a deadly bear trap. Utilizing these lethal weapons will drastically reduce the popularity of the party and as the numbers plummet, the level becomes increasingly tense.  As you reach the last dozen, opportunities are harder to come by. Thankfully, you are blessed with terrible dance moves so offensive, others will walk away from you shouting profanities behind them. Be careful though as annoying them too much may result in them beating you unconscious. As you stop the party with the exceptionally gruesome death of the DJ, you ironically dance alone like a maniac on the dance floor.  As you progress through the game, you visit a number of exotic locations and parties. Penthouse suites, executive yachts and even a party bus. Each has a brilliant soundtrack, which although on a loop, never outstayed its welcome. Each stage retains the random ethos with new haphazard such as wood-chippers, dancing bears and an infestation of zombies. Each level looks significantly different but I was shocked to see that, given the fact there are only a handful of stages available, one was a direct copy of a previous mission.  Sadly, the assortments of toys to play with can become dull and repetitive. Although at first, assassinating a large group with an explosion is fun, it soon becomes protocol. The majority of the killings are accomplished by the using the boring method of picking up a sleeping drunk, moving them to a secluded spot and murdering them discretely. The biggest frustration arises when the unfair AI can see you perform this act when seemingly behind cover. A particular level took me an hour to complete simply because of these frustrations which in turn found me becoming reckless to progress past the level. Party Hard is a game of patience yet instead of the meticulous nature feeling rewarding, it just became inattentive.  When the campaign is completed and depending on your performance, new characters can become available to you. Although they have similar skill-sets to Darius, they do differ slightly. A chainsaw wielding psycho can briefly decimate a number of people in a small radius whereas the crooked cop can accuse others of being the perpetrator. More bizarre levels unlock once the story has concluded too but the same formula remains.  Party Hard begins with an exciting concept. Being influenced by gory, pixel art games such as Hotline Miami; this mature, arcade slaughter fest has a lot of potential. Unfortunately, as in real life, returning to the same bar every weekend came become predictable and uneventful which parallels the issues within Party Hard. More diversity, modes and challenges could have reinvigorated this party but it should have called time a little earlier.  Pros:   Fun Premise   Random Levels   Fun Kills   Cons:   Repetitive   Lacks Variation   Unfair AI    My Score: 7.2/10

Who'd have thought? a literal 'Murder Simulator'. Heh.  Okay but seriously I want to recommend this but with something of a caveat. This review is based on the normal version of the game, not with the free DLC that's just released, as I haven't yet played that bit.  What we have here is effectively a face paced puzzle game where the puzzle shifts about dynamically and somewhat randomly. The puzzle is 'bunch of people are partying too loud'. The solution is 'kill everyone without being taken out'.  Your stock character has nice easy to understand mechanics. Stab people, drag their bodies around, or push people into environmental hazards, or heck just interact with parts of the environment to make things happen, like distract people with pizza, or summon zombies, or aliens, or a swat team or a chainsaw murderer, stuff like that. You know, normal things.  Guests react with horror at seeing dead bodies, so you will want to deal with that. or maybe not. depends on your strategy you're going for. Maybe the police and ambulance showing up could be a good thing. maybe you can pin the blame on someone else if you're quick and lucky enough. and that's a few less guests to deal with. Get spotted near a dead body and someone will try to call the police to get them to show up and arrest/kill you. Evade them long enough and they'll get bored and go back to their station or whatever (swat don't seem to though, nor do FBI), but each time the police are called it gets tougher to evade.  The game has multiple characters you can play, each with their own mechanics and each challenging the player in a different way. This helps things not get too stale, which is good. Though certain characters are just plainly awful to play as in certain situations unless you really want to challenge yourself.  As for the story (yes this game has one), I would say that it's actually rather interesting; perhaps a touch pedestrian and predictable, but enjoyable nonetheless and it kept me interested all the way through despite calling it right near the beginning as to what the twist was. You probably will as well, but even so it was an enjoyable, kind of silly game.  I'm not sure what the dlc changes or adds, but it is free so there's no worry there. Fan response to it seems divided however. Luckily, it's free. and it doesn't change the core game. only adds to it.  There's also a level editor as welll so you can design your own parties and such. I got several hours out of this game so I don't regret getting it really, and I'm going to recommend it wth the sidenote that the game really doesn't give any incentive for replaying it, kind of a 'One-and-done' sort of game, and the gameplay can get a touch repetitive, and frustrating, with luck due to random dynamic movement of guests around the parties causing some odd situations, sometimes favourable, sometimes crippling your run.  So basically, yes it's fun, but maybe not fun for everyone, and maybe its issues will turn you off the game before you can get far enough in it to complete it. Honestly in terms of 'the puzzle is dudes need to die, the solution is kill everyone' type gameplay, I feel the Hotline Miami games do it far better, and they have a better story too, but then they have a very different type of gameplay to Party Hard.

'Hitman meets Hotline Miami' is probably the best way I can describe Party Hard. Like any game featuring a certain bald-headed assassin, it's got open-ended levels with a wide variety of traps and accidents to trigger to throw a wrench into the game's social stealth-based AI, and like Dennaton's ultra-violent duology, the whole thing is presented with a kitschy 80's aesthetic featuring 8-bit graphics and synthwave music that is earworm-y as hell.   There are a ton of ways to go about your murdering sprees, but it's best to stay as subdued as possible, because your knife is slow and extremely short, and you can't sprint for very long if someone catches you carving into an innocent bystander. It seems like your movement and attacking are made intentionally crappy in order to prevent the game from being too easy, and this is compounded by certain assets and items in each level being randomized every time you play, so you'll always have to think of a new strategy when you replay levels because that one really useful trap isn't going to be there every time you replay it. It does make the game a little difficult, but I'm having so much fun just trying new stuff every time I replay a level that I don't really mind it so much. It's not perfect, but it's really fun, and for such a low price, you'd be crazy not to at least try it.
